entry.title: A classy chat with a friend
entry.summary:
I'm not dead, just preoccupied. (How's that for a soundbite bon mot quote sort of deal?). In fact, I've got a lovely bunch of coconutsdraft notes I need to sit down for and finally maybe make happen. That being said, sometimes an opportunity presents itself. Like, say, an IM chat with a friend of mine, whose blog you might be interested in perusing, if you're of the nerdy persuasion. And if you're reading this, odds are you might be.

Anyway, the conversation was about baby farts.

What? I told you it got classy.

Basically, here's a surprising fact you might not be even aware of. I know I wasn't, until I was over at my and my wife's friends' house, who had a baby before we did (PARENTING PROTIP: try and hang out with people with slightly older babies, that'll give you some heads-up on what to look out for in the coming months). They told us the baby was gassy and they're trying to get it to fart it all out.

Now, what we expected was, I don't know, maybe like a whistle sort of sound? What we emphatically did not expect was grown-ass old-man-style rancid dubstep tuba smackdown, which is what happened. Seriously, if I had to pick one answer for "what was the most surprising thing as a new parent?" question, that would be it. Because, as we soon learned from our own experience, all babies are like that. Anyway, here's a bit of the conversation, slightly edited for clarity and maybe an esprit de l'escalier or two:

Fuzzums: I think that's just to remind you that he's alive and well Me: I actually laughed at the idea irl. And I guess that might have actually happened already? Like when you're a real fresh parent and are like YO CHECK OUT THE BABY IF EVERYTHINGS OKAY IS IT STILL BREATHING OH GOD OH GOD in the dead of the night

And the baby's like BRRRRRRRRRRTTTTTTTTTTTT Fuzzums: he's like "I either scream or fart. They get all pissy when I scream, so farts it is" Me:: tbh I'm not sure if farts are connected to any particular emotional state at that developmental stage, not even the inherent hilarity Fuzzums: yeah, doubt it myself. but still

entry.title: Getting pelican to play well with Windows + GitHub...
entry.summary:
..or: how the sausage is made

Setting up this blog was a bit of a hassle. At least, compared to what I expected, based on what I know about git and Python, the two main technologies underlying the whole thing. I'm writing this in hopes that someone struggling with setting up the whole shebang will find that post and, hell who knows, maybe even find it useful. So, without further ado:

Pelican, the tool that's powering this blog, is a bit of a dick.

How's this for a catchy headline?

More to the point, its documentation, while otherwise pretty great, is somewhat lacking when it comes to using Pelican in a Windows environment.

Inb4 "Keph you dumb noob, turn in your nerd cred card for not using linux", I would -- and in fact, I have this celebrated nerd puzzle installed on a separate partition. Thing is, I have a laptop that runs in preposterously high resolution (3200x1800 on a 13" screen, and I have found it literally impossible to use Linux without at least some part of it looking like raw butts. This will probably end up as a separate post.

Anyway! First thing's first, you gotta get yourself some Python and get that shit installed. Personally, I would recommend you download Python 3.x, unless you're a seasoned developer dealing with legacy systems.

Hint: if all you're gonna be doing is running a blog, you're probably not.

And even if you are at your day job or wherever, this is irrelevant. I recommend you install that shit anyway as its own separate thing, IT'S ALL GOING TO BE OKAY, it's got its own separate folder and everything.

Note that this is not intended to be a full guide to working with Pelican. There's official instructions for that. I'm only here for some of the Windows-, and Github Pages-related gotchas I came across so far.

So, basically, follow the instructions right up until:

pip install pelican markdown

NOTE: It might be worth mentioning that, when you were installing Python, the installer's default is, curiously, not to add Python to your PATH environment variable. So if you left that unchecked and just rolled with it, you gotta add [whatever_you_installed_python_to] to the PATH, and, for good measure, [whatever_you_installed_python_to]\Scripts too, 'cause that's where pip sits.

Now, weird thing I noticed, the versions I installed from pip don't seem to pull in dependencies even though they should. So when you follow the quickstart instructions and type pelican-quickstart you might see Pelican borking the fuck out, like so:

ImportError: No module named some_module_or_other

There might be a better solution to this, but basically what I'd recommend is employing violence running python-quickstart repeatedly, seeing what module it was unable to load, then installing said module via pip. Repeat until beaten to a bloody pulp successful.

Now that you have both pelican and markdown installed, write your blog stuff, preferably in the content subdirectory of the project you just created with pelican-quickstart.

Compiling your blog to html

As far as I can tell, Pelican's supposed to make (haha, preemptive pun) the whole process crazy easy with a makefile or, if that's not your jam, a fabfile. Obviously, unless you go Cygwin or whatever, make's not an option. Thing is, if you're running Python 3, neither's fab. I... think? I read it's supposed to kinda, sorta work these days but personally, the most "success" I had with it is getting it to fuck up in different ways rather than just one. So... yay I guess?

So automation's out of the question, unless you roll your own. I guess it's a good thing then that it's fairly straightforward, huh?

Building a quick preview, so that you can see your theme's not fucked and your fancy formatting is displaying properly is dead simple, just run:

pelican content (Or substitute 'content' with wherever your source files for the blog are)

This'll generate the whole HTML bundle in the ./output directory right nearby.

Now, once you're production-ready, you simply add -s publishconf.py to the whole deal, like so:

pelican -s publishconf.py content

So since the ./output is what you'd put on your server, all you gotta do to make it work with github pages (click for instructions) is just: 1. Clone your site repo to that dir, 2. Run the command above, 3. Get that shit commited 4. git push like a bawss?

Right?

Fuck no, that would've been too simple.

...But don't worry, we're almost there!

See, thing about Pelican processing all that shit is it will nuke everything in the output dir unless you tell it otherwise.

Fortunately, that's a pretty easy fix, you just need to be aware of it. Basically, just open one of your config files, either pelicanconf.py or publishconf.py will do. I would recommend using the former. The latter imports all of pelicanconf.py's variables into its namespace anyway.

Now in said config, you gotta add:

OUTPUT_RETENTION = (".hg", ".git", ".bzr", "README.md")

Of course, feel free to add or remove anything to that tuple, that's what it's there for. Everything set in OUTPUT_RETENTION will not be deleted from the output directory. Fairly straightforward.

NOW you can go ahead and use that 4-step instruction guide just above, and you should be golden.

Now get blogging.

entry.title: Fathergasted
entry.summary:
One of the factors that drove me to my resolution of writing this here blog was that when my son was born earlier last year, I started... what's the word? Not microblogging, because I was definitely over twitter's limit. Not, strictly speaking, blogging, because a) it was still fairly short, and b) it was piggybacking on Facebook, of all things. Minifaceblogging? Idunno.

Anyway, before you say anything, I made a conscious decision to do whatever I can to not get sucked into your typical "new parent squees about babby that was formed". So no marvelling at poop, no overzealous diminutives -- basically, I tried to think about all the shit that would have pissed me off if I ever saw it on my FB wall, and then not do them. Whether I succeeded is not really mine to decide, though I hope that I managed to accomplish my goal at least to some degree.

So, about that title,

Originally, partly due to the majority of people on my FB speaking Polish, the posts were also in Polish. But there's another factor (apart from my incurable laziness): I couldn't come up with a decent English equivalent of the name I came up for the title, 'tactwo'. A portmanteau of the word for 'dad', and an ending '-ctwo' implying "I have no idea what I'm doing".

Which, let's face it, is every new parent's default state. I don't care how much theory you learned beforehand, how much you THINK you know, when all that (occasionally literal) shit goes down, you will find yourself not knowing what even the single solitary fuck.

Thanks to GargajCNS of IRC channel #imgurians fame, I think we finally have a decent equivalent that I feel encompasses all that I tried to convey with the title: fathergasted.

In this tag you will find posts I originally wrote for FB, except translated and made into a director's cut version, of sorts. Time and will permitting, of course.

Now that we've established what this is, one question remains: the blogging platform I'm currently using lets me do ORWELLIAN RETCONS OF REALITY backdate my posts. So should I set the date of the posts to what it originally was on FB, or just to whenever I got around to posting them? Hmm.

entry.title: Let's do this thing.
entry.summary:
At a loss for a better New Year's resolution, I found myself going with "do more creative things this year maybe". One of those things being, as you can see, "start a blog". Start another blog, to be exact. A new member in a prodigious line of blogs I kinda-sorta begun then completely forgot about, if we're being super-honest here.

And hey, this is the Internet, why would anyone ever lie to you on the Internet?

So I guess this is where some introductions are in order.

Hello, my name is Keph. Well not really, it's just a nick I've been using for long enough to pretentiously claim as my 'online identity'. I would still be bitter about Google+ not having agreed with that assertion a while back during the whole "nym wars" debacle, if anyone still gave a fuck about Google+.

As you can see, I tend to be somewhat liberal with my language, particularly all those bad words your mother probably advised you against using. If this blog were an animated gif, my advice to you would have been a pair of pixelated black eyewear slowly descending on someone's eyes, punctuated by "deal with it" in 72pt black caps-locked Impact.

Speaking of languages,

and this is where I take a swan dive into outright braggery and yet further into pretentiousness: I am fluent in 2 languages, English not even being my native one (Holy shit can you tell?!). So if this blog ever continues beyond this post, expect occasional posts in what I presume will be unpronounceable gibberish to you. Unless you can read Polish.

In a vain attempt at being helpful, I've already put this post in 'en' category which, if you're not into the whole Poland thing, you might possibly appreciate.

You know, if this ever goes anywhere. And since this is both another blog attempt AND a New Year resolution, I wouldn't exactly bet money on it. AND I'M THE AUTHOR.
